schema.avg_tenure_years: Average number of years people stay in one company
schema.distribution_pattern: Approximate proportions of short, medium, and long tenures
schema.edge_cases: Rare but realistic patterns (e.g. frequent switchers or long loyalists)

edge_cases.Frequent_Switchers: Some developers (especially in startups or contract roles) may switch every 8–12 months.
edge_cases.Long_Loyalists: System architects, DevOps leads, or senior engineers at FAANG or enterprise firms may stay 6–10 years.
edge_cases.Founders: Founding engineers in startups often show 4–8 year tenure (until acquisition or closure).

edge_cases.Frequent_Switchers: Analysts in investment banking often move within 2 years to PE, VC, or MBA programs.
edge_cases.Long_Loyalists: Wealth managers and CFO-track roles at banks may stay over 10 years.
edge_cases.Founders: Fintech founders average 5–7 years before exit or merger.

edge_cases.Frequent_Switchers: Analysts and associates often leave within 18 months for corporate strategy roles or MBA.
edge_cases.Long_Loyalists: Partners and senior consultants may stay 8–15 years in the same firm.
edge_cases.Founders: Some consulting professionals spin off boutique consultancies after 4–6 years.

edge_cases.Frequent_Switchers: Young clinical researchers may move often between hospitals or trials (1–2 year projects).
edge_cases.Long_Loyalists: Doctors in government or trust hospitals often serve for 10–20 years.
edge_cases.Founders: Healthcare entrepreneurs in diagnostics or telemedicine show 5–10 year engagement cycles.

edge_cases.Frequent_Switchers: Production engineers in Tier-2 suppliers may shift every 2 years for better pay.
edge_cases.Long_Loyalists: Managers and plant heads often stay 10–20 years, especially in public sector or large conglomerates.
edge_cases.Founders: Manufacturing entrepreneurs (automotive, materials) may run operations for decades.

edge_cases.Frequent_Switchers: Agency professionals often switch every year due to campaign-based work or burnout.
edge_cases.Long_Loyalists: CMOs or brand heads at legacy firms (FMCG, telecom) may stay 8–12 years.
edge_cases.Founders: Media agency founders usually have 7–10 year continuous tenures.

edge_cases.Frequent_Switchers: Adjunct lecturers or project researchers may change every academic cycle (1 year).
edge_cases.Long_Loyalists: Professors in universities typically serve 15–30 years.
edge_cases.Founders: EdTech startup founders may stay engaged for 5–8 years per venture.

edge_cases.Frequent_Switchers: Junior associates often switch firms within 1–2 years.
edge_cases.Long_Loyalists: Senior advocates or partners may stay with a chamber for life.
edge_cases.Founders: Policy think-tank founders or NGO leaders show 7–10 year tenures.

edge_cases.Frequent_Switchers: Field officers or NGO workers may rotate frequently between projects.
edge_cases.Long_Loyalists: Government or agricultural scientists often serve >15 years in one organization.
edge_cases.Founders: AgriTech founders may maintain 5–9 year runs per startup.

edge_cases.Frequent_Switchers: Lateral-entry officers or consultants may leave in 1–2 years.
edge_cases.Long_Loyalists: Civil servants and PSU employees often stay entire careers (25–35 years).
edge_cases.Founders: Policy entrepreneurs (advisors/startups working with govt) may shift projects every 3–4 years.

notes: Each industry's tenure distribution reflects typical retention behavior, career mobility, and edge cases like rapid switchers and long-term loyalists. Used to simulate realistic work histories in synthetic resume generation.
